messages.subject: Commercial Message
messages.msgSnippet: Hello all, Many Items on Nihontocraft.com are now on sale.  These items include 8 tosogu and 5 swords.  In addition to price reductions, new photography and
messages.messageBody:
Hello all,
Many Items on Nihontocraft.com are now on sale. These items include 8 tosogu and 5 swords. In addition to price reductions, new photography and information have been added to many of the presentations. Also, I have listed several rare books as well as a shinto wakizashi by Kozuke no kami Kanesada on eBay. Please take a look at the links below if you have any interest. Thank you.

http://www.nihontocraft.com/Nihonto_for_sale.html

http://www.nihontocraft.com/Tsuba_for_sale.html

http://search.ebay.com/_W0QQsassZsuppabQQhtZ-1QQfrppZ50QQfsopZ1QQfsooZ1QQrdZ0?

Best regards,
Danny Massey

messages.messageBody:
Greetings to all,
I have just added a Mino Senjuin naginata naoshi katana, Uda tanto, Musashi TairoYasukuni katana and two Owari tsuba to my web site. Also, in the sprit of good fun, I have listed a rare antique Wakizashi-Zutsu (sword traveling
case) on eBay with no reserve and no minimum bid. Please take a look at the link below if you have any interest. Thank you.

http://www.nihontocraft.com/japanese_sword_home.html

Best regards,
Danny Massey
www.nihontocraft.com

messages.subject: Commercial Message
messages.msgSnippet: Greetings to all, In addition to price reductions on the Aizu Kanesada and the Ikkasansai Yoshihiro, I have just added a wakizashi by Etchu Norifusa to my
messages.messageBody:
Greetings to all,
In addition to price reductions on the Aizu Kanesada and the Ikkasansai Yoshihiro, I have just added a wakizashi by Etchu Norifusa to my website. This study of this blade as well as the Ikkasansai Yoshihiro are wonderful leaning compliments to "Ura Nihon no Toko", by Yoshikawa Kentaro, which can be found in the articles section of the site. Please have a look if you are so inclined.

Best regards,
Danny Massey
www.nihontocraft.com

messages.messageBody:
Greetings to all,
I have just added an article entitled "Ura Nihon no Toko" by Yoshikawa Kentaro, to my website. Also, I have listed a fine koto Mihara katana that was worn by Colonel Goto in WWII. Please have a look if you are interested. Thank you

Best regards,
Danny Massey
www.nihontocraft.com

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Thoughts on this tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, Musashino.  The myoga and matsukawabishi don t normally have anything to do with the musashino design.  They re rather common decorative devices for
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
Musashino. The myoga and matsukawabishi don't normally have anything to do with the musashino design. They're rather common decorative devices for "making" hitsuana and were probably originally introduced as mon but then became part of the tsuba designer's vocabulary.

You're probably right about it being Owari. There are Owari guards with very Akasaka-esq designs that predate Akasaka. The seppa dai is quite broad at both the top and bottom. The rim isn't very rounded. The texture of the metal and the carving don't really fit Akasaka. The hitsuana treatment would be rather unusual for Akasaka. Looks like a nice guard.

Jim



Seasons greeting. Just back from holidays and arrived home to a new
piece for the collection. I purchased this guard as Ko Akasaka from a
trusted seller in Japan. I believe though that it is Owari. It has
outstanding colour and iron I think and is in wonderful condition. I
would put this as early Edo but happy to be corrected. There is a
similar tsuba listed in the Tsuba Taikan dated to the mid 1400's. It has
a great masashino theme but I am unsure of the relationship of the
ginger leaves and mon or pine tree as the hitsu ana. I have started to
wonder, as they have straight bars coming from both, if they are both
mon and in fact, war fans meeting on the grassy battle field. Anyway,
that's just some fanciful thought. Here are some images.

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/owari-masashino.jpg

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/owari-masashino-1.jpg

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/owari-masashino-2.jpg

It also has very fine running tekkotsu in the mimi, a lot like another
Edo Owari guard I have, just not as pronounced. This is the other mimi.

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/owari-mimi.jpg

Any thoughts or comments would be appreciated.

Note: the scan of the new tsuba makes the patina look a little odd, I am
unsure why this is, but it is in tact and very nice.

Kind regards

Rich Turner


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Thoughts on this tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Seasons greeting. Just back from holidays and arrived home to a new piece for the collection. I purchased this guard as Ko Akasaka from a trusted seller in
messages.messageBody:
Seasons greeting. Just back from holidays and arrived home to a new
piece for the collection. I purchased this guard as Ko Akasaka from a
trusted seller in Japan. I believe though that it is Owari. It has
outstanding colour and iron I think and is in wonderful condition. I
would put this as early Edo but happy to be corrected. There is a
similar tsuba listed in the Tsuba Taikan dated to the mid 1400's. It has
a great masashino theme but I am unsure of the relationship of the
ginger leaves and mon or pine tree as the hitsu ana. I have started to
wonder, as they have straight bars coming from both, if they are both
mon and in fact, war fans meeting on the grassy battle field. Anyway,
that's just some fanciful thought. Here are some images.

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/owari-masashino.jpg

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/owari-masashino-1.jpg

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/owari-masashino-2.jpg

It also has very fine running tekkotsu in the mimi, a lot like another
Edo Owari guard I have, just not as pronounced. This is the other mimi.

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/tsuba_collection/owari-mimi.jpg

Any thoughts or comments would be appreciated.

Note: the scan of the new tsuba makes the patina look a little odd, I am
unsure why this is, but it is in tact and very nice.

Kind regards

Rich Turner

messages.subject: Re: Re: [nihontostudy] Commercial Message
messages.msgSnippet: Jim , Thanks for your kind words about the gallery and the input on the Umetada Shigeyoshi. Honestly, I was perplexed about texture of the Shigeyoshi mimi.
messages.messageBody:
Jim ,
Thanks for your kind words about the gallery and the input on the Umetada Shigeyoshi. Honestly, I was perplexed about texture of the Shigeyoshi mimi. Thank you for providing some clarity. I believe you are correct and have updated the page to reflect your observations. Also, I left my initial thoughts there in the event that it may be helpful for those who see this texture in other works and mistakenly think it is a type of tekkotsu :-)

Best regards,
Danny

http://www.nihontocraft.com/Umetada_Shigeyoshi.html

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Commercial Message
messages.msgSnippet: Danny, Nice additions to the gallery.  The Umetada Shigeyoshi seems to have a carved (or etched) rim, rather than tekkotsu.  It looks like it was also
messages.messageBody:
Danny,
Nice additions to the gallery. The Umetada Shigeyoshi seems to have a carved (or etched) rim, rather than tekkotsu. It looks like it was also decorated with nunome zogan. It's an unusual tsuba.

Jim



Greetings from Nihontocraft.com

Five Tsubas have been added to the gallery for everyone's study and enjoyment.

They are as follows: Published Katsusada katchushi tsuba , Katchushi Rinbo
tsuba, Hozon Myochin Moritsugu tsuba , Hozon Umetada Shigeyoshi tsuba and a
Tokubetsu Hozon Umetada Munetake tsuba. Here is a link to the gallery:

http://www.nihontocraft.com/japanese_sword_gallery.html


Recent updates and additions to items available for purchase are as follows :
Antique Noh theater hannya demon mask, Shoami tsuba with NTHK papers and the
price of the Yamaoka Tesshu calligraphy has been reduced. Below are links to
these items.:

http://www.nihontocraft.com/noh_theater_demon_mask.html

http://www.nihontocraft.com/Owari_Tsuba.html

http://www.nihontocraft.com/Yamaoka_Tesshu.html

Please take a look if you are so inclined.

Best regards,
Danny Massey
www.nihontocraft.com
